title: Digiday+ Research: A guide to ad-supported streaming services, from the top
excerpt: The first installment of Digiday's two-part series on the top ad-supported streaming services provides an overview of the platforms’ offerings and an analysis of how brands and agencies distribute their ad budgets and ad placements across platforms.

title: Research Briefing: Frequency capping matters most on streaming platforms
excerpt: In this edition of the Digiday+ Research Briefing, we examine the top ad attributes marketers want from ad-supported streaming platforms, how brands are increasing their marketing spend on YouTube, and how Walmart and Roblox are teaming up to make virtual e-commerce a reality, as seen in recent data from Digiday+ Research.

title: What You Need to Know About U.S. Sports TV Contracts
excerpt: The NFL's television contracts account for $12.4 billion, about 43% of all sports TV deals in the U.S.

title: Understanding YouTube Campaign Types
excerpt: Google Ads offers seven YouTube campaign subtypes, ranging from reaching users while browsing to driving conversions.

title: The Untold History of the ‘Whassup?’ Super Bowl Commercial
excerpt: How a grainy VHS tape became one of the most famous ads of all time — and went viral before viral was even a thing.

title: Art, Commerce, and Zamfir: Selling Music on TV
excerpt: Not sold in stores. Duhhhhhh.Neatorama is proud to bring you a guest post from Ernie Smith, the editor of Tedium, a twice-weekly newsletter that hunts for the end of the long tail. title: The Economics of Infomercials - Priceonomics
excerpt: At $200 billion, the infomercial industry is twice the size of the entire TV business. How is that possible? We investigate the business model behind the Snuggie.

title: Anatomy of a Product Placement (Published 2022)
excerpt: As consumers skip ads and streaming content balloons, brands aim to be everywhere all at once.

title: Roku
excerpt: Roku provides the simplest way to stream entertainment to your TV. On your terms. With thousands of available channels to choose from.

title: TV Advertising’s Surprising Strength — And Inevitable Fall
excerpt: TV advertising is having a good week at the upfronts, and it may be more resilient than expected. That, though, means the crash will be even more abrupt.

title: The economics of movie product placements
excerpt: Today’s films are brimming with products from big-name brands. How exactly do these partnerships work? And is the payoff worth it?
